What I hope to see from a salesman who is trying to get our business:  1) Come prepared.  Have at least an idea of what our menu is, because pitching Chinese food to a sports bar just doesn't make sense.  2) Don't bash our current supplier.  I use them for a reason.  I trust them more than I trust someone off the street. You don't have any upside with me by doing this.  3) I don't want to be pitched a random item if we haven't met before.  I'm sure you have great meat and I'm sure you have a great IPA. I don't care, everyone does.   Start by asking us about what we're looking for and follow up next week with what we talk about.  4) Don't stop in during peak hours, unless you have reason to believe we're slow.  An unsolicited sales pitch during lunch isn't going to do anything but piss me off, especially if we've never met.  5) If you come in for lunch with a friend & I'm your server, and you've spent the last month trying to get my business, you damn well better leave a tip. I do not care about the $5.  I do care about how you act in a restaurant (and, yes, this actually happened).  6) If I ask for a quote on a dozen items, and you promise me you'll have it done by Friday, then I need it by Friday.  If you flake out on the first agreement we make together, you're going to flake on the rest of our relationship as well.  7) Eventually you're going to have to offer something I can't get with my current suppliers.  They are the incumbent.  The incumbent has a huge advantage.  If I'm even marginally happy with my current supplier, I need to think I have upside with you-because switching from something that works is nothing but downside.  8) Don't talk down to my staff.  I've seen this.  Instant, irreversible turn off.  As I read through all of this, it basically comes down to this: build trust. There's many ways to do this, but there's just as many ways to lose it. Controversial opinion. Use Bubble to build your SaaS.    Why? Because for every billion dollar idea you have, 10,000 other people had the same idea, and are building it right now.  Are you in this to make money? Build a business? Work for yourself? Become your own boss? Retire? Quit your job?   OR are you in this because you like Javascript?  Whatever your motivation is, he who is first, wins.  No code is a game-changer for rapid market entry and product validation.  Here's the deal: Only code after confirming market demand for your app.  Why this approach? Because, despite what a lot of founders/devs think, saas is just like any other business.   Supply and demand, but this time the supply is the lack of a solution for a problem a lot of people have.  And the competition is a lot more fierce. You're up against the best in the business.  Consider this: Your 'billion-dollar SaaS concept' could take over half a year to develop traditionally. But with Bubble, you're ahead in mere weeks.  And, let's face it, even your great aunt has 3 multi billion dollar app ideas a day, so whats to say yours is any different?  What's your fallback when traditional coding and months of work lead to a dead end?  Passion for coding is great, but it doesn't pay bills.   Customers won't flock to your app because you have the best tech stack.  Yet, with no-code tools, you can carve a niche, outmanoeuvre competitors, and craft a thriving business.  A lot of the time you can get quite far with your bubble MVP, you can monetise it, build a scalable business, and then, once you hit your revenue goals, develop it properly/hire someone.  Too many founders get stuck in the mindset that they need to have everything self coded because "Bubble reduces exit value" or "I don't own my product".  When in reality, the dude buying your business cares about 2 things:  1) TTM Profit 2) Market size  If they see good numbers in these two things, then your business is worth something.   Maybe slightly lower multiplier if its in no code, but at least you have a product with paying users.   Because while Nathan is googling how to centre a div, you've launched an MVP and are already scooping up market share.  The moral of this is, if you spend 6-12 months building, someone will always get there first.   The person who wins, is the one who gets there first.  It worked for me, why wouldnt it work for you.

I feel that it's quite dishonest how Joel Greenblatt sells small investors the idea that outperformance can be achieved solely through quantitive business factors  Both in this article, and in books such as "The Little Book that Beats the Market", etc, he often cites to periods in history where can can do screens for stocks at certain valuations, such as 1972-1978, and his broad claim is that:   "Because there are periods where stock groups in certain quantitive ranges, ranked off of 1-50 characteristics, outperform other stocks, that makes you capable of picking stock groups solely based off of these quantitive factors in different time periods to outperform"  I find Joel Greenblatt very smartly sells people an incomplete investing philosophy through articles like this, or books with similar philosophy, without ever proving or showing any evidence that outperformance comes from what he's showing. He's just selling the dream that you can go pick 10-30 stocks in certain valuation ranges and outperform  Efficient market theory didn't debunk that you can find individual securities that outperform, but it absolutely debunked the philosophy that Joel Greenblatt is teaching in this article:   The philosophy that you can just buy groups of stocks in certain valuation ranges and show actual outperformance  If you average 2 separate groups of people or 2 groups of stocks based off any amount of identity characteristics, their averaged behavior will be guaranteed to be different in any measured characteristic. This is why you don't want to evaluate groups more than "I'll look through the things below book value" and then you're still making your investment decisions completely on individuality and on a combination of qualitative and quantitive factors  You can't do that when you just consider quantitive factors, therefore you can't really complete the process, in the way Warren Buffett would teach investing, to make investing decisions to ever expect to outperform  Joel Greenblatt doesn't attack the right part of efficient market theory, which is to attack the nature of what makes a business a business, through qualitative factors that can't be written down and predicted with algorithms that only see numbers  In summary: I think he way too often teaches the misguided philosophy that there's something to learn from screens through historical valuation ranges without looking at actual business factors such as "where's the business at and what does that mean", "Who runs the business", etc, etc...

These 20 lessons will teach you more than a 4-year business degree:  1. There is no get-rich-quick scheme. You need a mixture of hard work, patience and a great idea.  2. Set a large goal and reverse engineer it. Breaking your goals down into bite-sized chunks can make success more achievable in the short and long-term.  3. Trust your gut instinct. If you go against it and it doesn’t work out you will regret it.  4. Get a mentor or coach who has done what you want to do. Make sure you have someone to share experiences, ideas and feedback with.  5. Family have their place in this journey, but don’t rely on them for anything other than support.  6. Make sure you know who your target market is. Make it specific.  7. Sell a service rather than a product. The upside and pitfalls are much better for a service offering.  8. A CEO is the answer to all questions. The solver of all problems. The head of all departments. Be the expert.  9. Prepare for the first years of the business to be selfish and time-consuming. Find balance where you can.  10. Doing the easy things is not actually easy. You need to work at it every day.  11. Concentrate on the small wins. Eventually the big wins take care of themselves.  12. Fight for every deal, no matter how lost it seems.  13. Setting up a company to make a difference will be the best option in the short and long term. Don’t just do it for the money.  14. If you own the company, you’re accountable for everything. Embrace this mindset.  15. Work ethic and talent are the two drivers of hiring success. Make sure you recruit well.  16. Failure can be acceptable. Excuses are not. Make sure you identify both.  17. When you finish a year, make time for an honest review to reflect. This is the perfect time to make changes.  18. Assess your success at all possible opportunities and listen to external feedback from clients at all times.  19. You are what your record says at the end of the day, regardless of how hard you try.  20. Build a business for the future as well as the present. Make long-term relationships that can benefit the company in future years.
